awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Increasing bandwidth to the brain via effective stimulation of the peripheral retina in virtual image displays
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will explore ways to increase bandwidth to the brain though optimal spatial-temporal simulation of the far peripheral retina.  There are many questions related to the functionality of the far periphery and how it engenders of a sense of place and presence within a virtual environment.  To address these questions this project will develop: (1) a state-of-the-art retinal image projection system that can generate and position spatial patterns of light encompassing the complete retina; (2) methods for measuring the effect of that stimulation on the brain wave activity, balance and task performance; and (3) new approaches for organizing and portraying information over the complete retina that increase throughput of data to the brain. The research from this project can lead to development of better virtual reality components that unlock the power of human intelligence and link minds globally. This line of research is essential as the industry presses for optimizing the utility of 5G cellular bandwidths in servicing wireless and ubiquitous virtual and augmented displays via WebVR and related systems.  

This project will investigate how to input the autonomic nervous system to enhance the cognitive behavior of users. A key component in the research agenda is to design and build an experimental system that generates and positions patterns of light stimuli onto the various regions and eccentricities of the entire visual field of the participant.  This system must allow for the precise generation of the spatial, temporal and spectral properties of these stimuli.  These factors constitute the independent variables in the research.  Similarly, this research apparatus must also collect the voluntary and involuntary behavioral response of the participant to these stimuli using direct methods that include event-related cortical potentials, oculomotor behavior and involuntary movement of the body (e.g., posture platform).  Voluntary or performance-based tracking and manipulation of the virtual world experience will also be included in the experimental apparatus.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Eager Grant #1845910 Report (Codename: GLINT)

Introduction

The Eager Grant project, codename GLINT, aimed to explore and characterize the functionality of the far peripheral retina in the human visual system. This research was motivated by the resurgence of interest in virtual reality (VR) and questions regarding the necessary visual field size to generate an immersive experience or a sense of presence in a virtual world.

Background

Histological examination of the human retina shows that light receptors (rods and cones) provide a field of vision up to 240 degrees (angles off-center of +/- 120 degrees, termed eccentricities). However, it is unclear how much of this total field of vision is brought into consciousness and necessary to ‘feel’ present in a computer-generated environment.

Experimentation

Experiment 1: Detection of Moving Objects

In the GLINT project, investigators conducted several experiments to address the following questions:

  1. How much of the total visual field are people consciously aware of (or can detect)?
  2. Is there evidence of perception (the ability to recognize objects) without conscious awareness?

The first set of experiments involved 16 subjects (8 males and 8 females) with normal vision. They indicated the boundary or eccentricity (angle from straight ahead) at which they could see black-filled circular objects of two sizes (2.5 or 7 degrees) on a light green background. These objects moved at 3.0 degrees per second horizontally from the back to the front of their visual fields. Additionally, subjects indicated when they stopped seeing objects moving from the front to the back of their visual fields. Vertical movement of the black object was switched on and off with a 10-degree vertical amplitude and an oscillation frequency of 1.0 Hz.

Results:

The mean detection angles of the stimuli in the horizontal plane for all subjects varied from 96 degrees to 107 degrees from the front fixation point, with an average of 101 degrees of eccentricity or a 202-degree total field of view. The eccentricities of object detection increased significantly when the objects were larger and when there was vertical oscillation.

Experiment 2: Recognition of Static Shapes

The objective of the second experiment was to determine the accuracy of recognition of four static shapes (circle, triangle, X, square), each subtending 5 degrees and presented randomly at different eccentricities from 65 to 120 degrees. The same display configuration and subjects from the first experiment were used. This range of eccentricities included angles outside the conscious vision limits established in the first experiment.

Results:

Recognition accuracy declined as eccentricities approached the limit of conscious awareness. However, even at eccentricities beyond conscious vision, subjects still showed significant recognition beyond chance. Subjects often noted that they couldn’t see the object but were instructed to make their best guess. Remarkably, their guesses were significantly above chance, indicating perception without awareness.

Additional Experiments

Other experiments investigated how the field of view affects the autonomic nervous system, particularly postural stability or balance. It is well-documented that human balance is derived from a combination of visual and vestibular cues. People can generally maintain balance with their eyes closed. This experiment introduced a conflict between vestibular-derived balance cues and those from the visual scene (e.g., the person is stationary but the visual scene is moving) and observed the effect on balance using a posture platform. The larger the visual scene, the more conflict and imbalance were observed. The amount of disturbance in balance indicated the sensitivity of the increasing visual field size on the autonomic nervous system.

Another experiment measured the autonomic balance response of stationary subjects while watching wide field of view random moving scenes and used deviations in balance as an input to null the movement of the visual scene. In this way, the body became a joystick without any conscious effort of the subject.

Conclusion

The GLINT project met its objective of exploring the functionalities of the far peripheral retina and developed a toolkit for further exploration of human factors associated with far peripheral displays and increasing bandwidth to the brain. The findings reveal that the current state of the art in virtual reality displays (approximately 120-140 degrees) does not approach the limits of conscious vision (approximately 200 degrees) and are not yet optimal portals for delivering visual information to the brain.

The most striking finding is the evidence of perception without awareness in the region beyond the limit of conscious vision (200-240 degrees). Investigators believe that these findings should be extended to explore the possibility of building new 'inconspicuous displays' that use the far periphery as a portal to provide bandwidth to the brain without requiring attention or conscious thought.
